div.head: Robert Melville Grindlay (1786-1877)
div.p: Grindlay was an amateur artist, whose drawings formed the basis of engravings published by Smith, Elder & Company. Grindlay's Scenery, Costumes and Architecture, Chiefly on the Western Side of India was published in engraving and aquatint, in part by Rudolph Ackermann and in full by Smith, Elder, between 1826 and 1830. A sketch by Grindlay from travel in Italy also was worked into an engraving for Smith, Elder's annual, Friendship's Offering, in 1830 (see Saltzburg.

From 1803, Grindlay served in the East India Company's military service (the Bombay Native Infantry) and other official positions, which enabled him to travel extensively throughout western India. Retiring from the service in 1817 and returning to England, in 1828 (?) Grindlay founded a London agency, Leslie & Grindlay, for shipping and passenger travel to and from India. The agency, which eventually grew into a major Anglo-Indian banking firm, was situated in Birchin Lane, near the second location of Smith, Elder, at 65, Cornhill (Rohatgi and Parlett, Indian Life and Landscape by Western Artists, 213-16). As both firms dealt in Anglo-Indian travel and trade, it seems likely that Grindlay and Alexander Elder were brought together by their shared artistic as well as business interests.
